elements.content: A 5-substituted benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (1,3-BDC), 5-(N-phthalimide)isophthalic acid (5-NPIA), reacts with CuCl2 to afford either a Kagomé lattice or NbO nets, depending upon which solvent is used for the reaction.
elements.clean_text: A 5-substituted benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (1,3-BDC), 5-(N-phthalimide)isophthalic acid (5-NPIA), reacts with CuCl2 to afford either a Kagomé lattice or NbO nets, depending upon which solvent is used for the reaction.

elements.content: A 5-substituted benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (1,3-BDC), 5-(N-phthalimide)isophthalic acid (5-NPIA), reacts with CuCl2 to afford either a Kagomé lattice or NbO nets, depending upon which solvent is used for the reaction.
elements.clean_text: A 5-substituted benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (1,3-BDC), 5-(N-phthalimide)isophthalic acid (5-NPIA), reacts with CuCl2 to afford either a Kagomé lattice or NbO nets, depending upon which solvent is used for the reaction.

elements.content: The past decade has witnessed explosive growth in the study of metal−organic materials (MOMs), at least partly because they exhibit unprecedented levels of permanent porosity, but also because the design principles that have been developed for MOMs engender chemical and structural diversity which facilitates tuning of bulk properties. In terms of design, the “node and linker” approach was pioneered by Wells and Robson, who used network inorganic crystal structures as blueprints for coordination polymers sustained by metal ions (the node) and multifunctional organic ligands (the linkers). Extending this strategy, nodes from [M2(carboxylate)4] square paddlewheels or [M4O(carboxylate)6] tetrahedra afforded the first examples of extra large surface area MOMs, HKUST-1, and MOF-5, respectively. These permanently porous MOMs exhibit surface areas exceeding all other classes of porous materials. Today, there are already >10,000 MOMs that have been deposited in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). However, there remain only a limited number of readily accessible, high symmetry nets that are the result of linking polygonal or polyhedral nodes such as tetrahedra (dia), octahedra (pcu), squares (NbO), trigonal prisms (acs), and faceted polyhedra (rht). Such nets could be described as platforms or blueprints because they are fine-tunable in terms of both scale and properties, as there are many nodes and linkers that can sustain these structures. The prototypal MOMs for these topologies exploit simple multifunctional ligands or their derivatives. In the case of carboxylate ligands, benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (1,3-BDC), benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (1,4-BDC), and benzene-1,3,5-dicarboxylic acid (BTC) have been widely utilized. Whereas BTC is predisposed to form HKUST-1 when it coordinates to [M2(carboxylate)4] square paddlewheels, 1,3-BDC and 1,4-BDC can exist in more than one supramolecular isomer. In this contribution, we report how a derivative of 1,3-BDC forms two supramolecular isomers with [M2(carboxylate)4] paddlewheels, one of which exists as an NbO net. The NbO topology has only been generated once with [M2(carboxylate)4] paddlewheels as the unique 4-connected node in a tour de force of crystal engineering that demonstrated how the conformation of the carboxylate moieties in 1,4-BDC can impart control over a network formed from square paddlewheels.
elements.clean_text: The past decade has witnessed explosive growth in the study of metal-organic materials (MOMs), at least partly because they exhibit unprecedented levels of permanent porosity, but also because the design principles that have been developed for MOMs engender chemical and structural diversity which facilitates tuning of bulk properties. In terms of design, the "node and linker" approach was pioneered by Wells and Robson, who used network inorganic crystal structures as blueprints for coordination polymers sustained by metal ions (the node) and multifunctional organic ligands (the linkers). Extending this strategy, nodes from [M2(carboxylate)4] square paddlewheels or [M4O(carboxylate)6] tetrahedra afforded the first examples of extra large surface area MOMs, HKUST-1, and MOF-5, respectively. These permanently porous MOMs exhibit surface areas exceeding all other classes of porous materials. Today, there are already >10,000 MOMs that have been deposited in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). However, there remain only a limited number of readily accessible, high symmetry nets that are the result of linking polygonal or polyhedral nodes such as tetrahedra (dia), octahedra (pcu), squares (NbO), trigonal prisms (acs), and faceted polyhedra (rht). Such nets could be described as platforms or blueprints because they are fine-tunable in terms of both scale and properties, as there are many nodes and linkers that can sustain these structures. The prototypal MOMs for these topologies exploit simple multifunctional ligands or their derivatives. In the case of carboxylate ligands, benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (1,3-BDC), benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (1,4-BDC), and benzene-1,3,5-dicarboxylic acid (BTC) have been widely utilized. Whereas BTC is predisposed to form HKUST-1 when it coordinates to [M2(carboxylate)4] square paddlewheels, 1,3-BDC and 1,4-BDC can exist in more than one supramolecular isomer. In this contribution, we report how a derivative of 1,3-BDC forms two supramolecular isomers with [M2(carboxylate)4] paddlewheels, one of which exists as an NbO net. The NbO topology has only been generated once with [M2(carboxylate)4] paddlewheels as the unique 4-connected node in a tour de force of crystal engineering that demonstrated how the conformation of the carboxylate moieties in 1,4-BDC can impart control over a network formed from square paddlewheels.

elements.content: The Cambridge Structural Database, CSD (version 5.31), contains over 2000 entries that contain 1,3-BDC moieties coordinated to metals, and 229 of these structures are MOMs that contain 1,3-BDC moieties bonded to square paddlewheels. In our laboratory, we have demonstrated how structural diversity or supramolecular isomerism is possible from either simple or covalently cross-linked 1,3-BDC derivatives. Figure reveals how 1,3-BDC can be regarded as “partially flexible” in that, although its two carboxylate moieties must subtend at 120°, the carboxylate moieties can twist or bend with respect to the plane of the benzene ring and, therefore, facilitate supramolecular isomerism through conformational diversity. A CSD analysis reveals that the twist angles in coordinated 1,3-BDC ligands can range from 0 to 90° and, perhaps surprisingly, that bend angles can be as high as 29.7°. Discrete nanoballs, Kagomé lattice nets, and square grid nets exemplify the structures formed from 1,3-BDC linked paddlewheels.
elements.clean_text: The Cambridge Structural Database, CSD (version 5.31), contains over 2000 entries that contain 1,3-BDC moieties coordinated to metals, and 229 of these structures are MOMs that contain 1,3-BDC moieties bonded to square paddlewheels. In our laboratory, we have demonstrated how structural diversity or supramolecular isomerism is possible from either simple or covalently cross-linked 1,3-BDC derivatives. Figure  reveals how 1,3-BDC can be regarded as "partially flexible" in that, although its two carboxylate moieties must subtend at 120°, the carboxylate moieties can twist or bend with respect to the plane of the benzene ring and, therefore, facilitate supramolecular isomerism through conformational diversity. A CSD analysis reveals that the twist angles in coordinated 1,3-BDC ligands can range from 0 to 90° and, perhaps surprisingly, that bend angles can be as high as 29.7°. Discrete nanoballs, Kagomé lattice nets, and square grid nets exemplify the structures formed from 1,3-BDC linked paddlewheels.

elements.content: The “partial flexibility” of 1,3-BDC can sustain twist angles of 0−90° or bend angles of up to 29.7°.
elements.clean_text: 1  The "partial flexibility" of 1,3-BDC can sustain twist angles of 0-90° or bend angles of up to 29.7°.

elements.content: However, a bulky substituent at the 5-position of 1,3-BDC can induce twisting or bending of BDC ligands and facilitate even greater diversity in the form of CdSO4 and “USF-1” topologies. 5-(N-phthalimide)isophthalic acid (5-NPIA) also possesses a bulky imide group at its 5-position, and we herein describe the first MOMs sustained by 5-NPIA. 5-NPIA was synthesized as described in the literature, and reaction of 5-NPIA with CuCl2 at 85 °C afforded two supramolecular isomers of formula Cu2(5-NPIA)2S2, a Kagomé lattice (S = diethylformamide, DEF) or an NbO net (S = dimethylacetamide, DMA).
elements.clean_text: However, a bulky substituent at the 5-position of 1,3-BDC can induce twisting or bending of BDC ligands and facilitate even greater diversity in the form of CdSO4 and "USF-1" topologies. 5-(N-phthalimide)isophthalic acid (5-NPIA) also possesses a bulky imide group at its 5-position, and we herein describe the first MOMs sustained by 5-NPIA. 5-NPIA was synthesized as described in the literature, and reaction of 5-NPIA with CuCl2 at 85 °C afforded two supramolecular isomers of formula Cu2(5-NPIA)2S2, a Kagomé lattice (S = diethylformamide, DEF) or an NbO net (S = dimethylacetamide, DMA).

elements.content: The geometry of 5-NPIA and the paddlewheel moieties: green, plane of the benzene ring in 5-NPIA; yellow, planes of the two carboxylate moieties of 5-NPIA.
elements.clean_text: 2  The geometry of 5-NPIA and the paddlewheel moieties: green, plane of the benzene ring in 5-NPIA; yellow, planes of the two carboxylate moieties of 5-NPIA.

elements.content: 5-NPIA and CuCl2 were reacted in 5 mL of DEF and 1 mL of ethanol at 85 °C for 2 days. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue hexagon shaped crystals of formula [{Cu2(5-NPIA)2(DEF)2·1.35DEF·0.4EtOH} n ] (1) were afforded. Single crystal X-ray crystallography revealed that 1 adopts space group C2/m and that its topology is that of a 2D Kagomé lattice. The Cu2+ cations adopt square pyramidal geometry, since they each coordinate to four oxygen atoms from μ2-η1:η1 carboxylates and DEF molecules occupy the axial sites of the paddlewheels. The paddlewheels are linked by 1,3-BDC moieties to form 2D Kagomé lattice sheets, which pack via π···π stacking () and hydrogen bonding interactions. As depicted in Figure , the imide groups in the two crystallographically independent 5-NPIAs rotate substantially from planarity (57° and 58° with respect to the plane of the BDC benzene ring (green)). The two square paddlewheel moieties (yellow) subtend angles of 7°, 10°, and 12° with respect to the plane, respectively. In terms of topology, if the copper paddlewheels are treated as 4-connected nodes and the 5-NPIA ligands as linkers, 1 exhibits the Kagomé topology (Figure ) with (Schläfli) symbol {32·62·72}.
elements.clean_text: 5-NPIA and CuCl2 were reacted in 5 mL of DEF and 1 mL of ethanol at 85 °C for 2 days. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue hexagon shaped crystals of formula [{Cu2(5-NPIA)2(DEF)2⋅1.35DEF⋅0.4EtOH} n ] (1) were afforded. Single crystal X-ray crystallography revealed that 1 adopts space group C2/m and that its topology is that of a 2D Kagomé lattice. The Cu2+ cations adopt square pyramidal geometry, since they each coordinate to four oxygen atoms from μ2-η1:η1 carboxylates and DEF molecules occupy the axial sites of the paddlewheels. The paddlewheels are linked by 1,3-BDC moieties to form 2D Kagomé lattice sheets, which pack via π⋅⋅⋅π stacking () and hydrogen bonding interactions. As depicted in Figure , the imide groups in the two crystallographically independent 5-NPIAs rotate substantially from planarity (57° and 58° with respect to the plane of the BDC benzene ring (green)). The two square paddlewheel moieties (yellow) subtend angles of 7°, 10°, and 12° with respect to the plane, respectively. In terms of topology, if the copper paddlewheels are treated as 4-connected nodes and the 5-NPIA ligands as linkers, 1 exhibits the Kagomé topology (Figure ) with (Schläfli) symbol {32⋅62⋅72}.

elements.content: The 2D layer of 1 (left) and its node and linker connectivity (right) that identifies it as a Kagomé lattice network.
elements.clean_text: 3  The 2D layer of 1 (left) and its node and linker connectivity (right) that identifies it as a Kagomé lattice network.

elements.content: The same reaction conducted using 5 mL of DMA and 1 mL of methanol instead of 5 mL of DEF and 1 mL of ethanol afforded blue block crystals of formula [{Cu2(5-NPIA)2(DMA)2} n ] (2). 2 crystallizes in space group R3̅ and exhibits a 3D network with narrow channels of ∼3.0 Å × 3.0 Å parallel to the c axis. There is one crystallographic independent 5-NPIA, which generates an angle of 40° from the plane of the imide group to the plane of the benzene plane. The two square paddlewheel moieties subtend angles of 19° and 24° with respect to the plane of the BDC benzene ring. If the square paddlewheel moieties are treated as 4-connected nodes and the 5-NPIA ligands as linkers, then 2 exhibits the NbO topology with (Schläfli) symbol {64·82}2{66} (Figure ). To our knowledge, 2 is the first example of NbO topology from square paddlewheel moieties linked by a substituted 1,3-BDC. NbO is a desirable topology because its 3D structure is open and necessarily noninterpenetrating, since NbO is not self-dual (a body-centered cubic network is its dual). In 2, the large apertures and voids in the structure are occupied by the pyromellitic imide group and DMA molecules that are coordinated to the axial metal sites of the square paddlewheel moieties. Removal of DMA solvent molecules would create an accessible free volume of 3002.6 Å3, which is 33.5% of the volume of the unit cell (PLATON).
elements.clean_text: The same reaction conducted using 5 mL of DMA and 1 mL of methanol instead of 5 mL of DEF and 1 mL of ethanol afforded blue block crystals of formula [{Cu2(5-NPIA)2(DMA)2} n ] (2). 2 crystallizes in space group R3̅ and exhibits a 3D network with narrow channels of ~3.0 Å × 3.0 Å parallel to the c axis. There is one crystallographic independent 5-NPIA, which generates an angle of 40° from the plane of the imide group to the plane of the benzene plane. The two square paddlewheel moieties subtend angles of 19° and 24° with respect to the plane of the BDC benzene ring. If the square paddlewheel moieties are treated as 4-connected nodes and the 5-NPIA ligands as linkers, then 2 exhibits the NbO topology with (Schläfli) symbol {64⋅82}2{66} (Figure ). To our knowledge, 2 is the first example of NbO topology from square paddlewheel moieties linked by a substituted 1,3-BDC. NbO is a desirable topology because its 3D structure is open and necessarily noninterpenetrating, since NbO is not self-dual (a body-centered cubic network is its dual). In 2, the large apertures and voids in the structure are occupied by the pyromellitic imide group and DMA molecules that are coordinated to the axial metal sites of the square paddlewheel moieties. Removal of DMA solvent molecules would create an accessible free volume of 3002.6 Å3, which is 33.5% of the volume of the unit cell (PLATON).

elements.content: (a) Partially expanded net of 2 showing the NbO topology; (b) packing of the 3D structure of 2 viewed along the c axis. For clarity, the pyromellitic imide groups and coordinated DMA are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Partially expanded net of 2 showing the NbO topology; (b) packing of the 3D structure of 2 viewed along the c axis. For clarity, the pyromellitic imide groups and coordinated DMA are omitted.

elements.content: To evaluate the stability of the two complexes, thermogravimetric analysis was conducted (). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits an initial weight loss about 1.5% to 80 °C, which can be ascribed to the loss of free ethanol (1.5% calculated) in the lattice. The sample is stable to 150 °C, at which point decomposition occurs. 2 exhibits much higher thermal stability (up to 292 °C without weight loss), but then an uninterrupted weight loss of ∼80% was observed, presumably corresponding to the loss of DMA molecules and decomposition of the framework.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the stability of the two complexes, thermogravimetric analysis was conducted (). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits an initial weight loss about 1.5% to 80 °C, which can be ascribed to the loss of free ethanol (1.5% calculated) in the lattice. The sample is stable to 150 °C, at which point decomposition occurs. 2 exhibits much higher thermal stability (up to 292 °C without weight loss), but then an uninterrupted weight loss of ~80% was observed, presumably corresponding to the loss of DMA molecules and decomposition of the framework.

elements.content: The angles θ, ψ, and φ used to quantify the distortion of the 1,3-BDC and 1,4-BDC ligands.
elements.clean_text: 5  The angles θ, ψ, and φ used to quantify the distortion of the 1,3-BDC and 1,4-BDC ligands.

elements.content: As mentioned earlier, Kagomé, square grid, and discrete nanoballs are the most commonly encountered nets when 1,3-BDC ligands serve as linkers for square paddlewheel moieties, although other supramolecular isomers such as USF-1, CdSO4, and MOF-112 nets have also been observed. We can now add NbO to this list, and the promiscuity of this system raises questions about how subtle geometric and steric factors might influence which nets will be obtained for a particular combination of nodes and linkers. The geometric features of 1,3-BDC or 1,4-BDC afford three geometric parameters that address bending or twisting as follows (Figure ): bending in the middle of the link by an angle θ; bending of the planes of the carboxylates by an angle ψ; twisting of the planes of the carboxylates about the linker axis relative to each other by an angle φ. We analyzed crystal structures that involve square paddlewheels linked by 1,3-BDC or 1,4-BDC, and the experimentally observed values of θ, ψ, and φ are presented in Table . 1,3-BDC forms Kagomé, square grid, nanoball-1, nanoball-2, CdSO4, USF-1, mot, and NbO nets, whereas 1,4-BDC is only known to exist as Kagomé, square grid, CdSO4, or NbO nets. It is interesting to note that six of these topologies can be grouped into three related pairs: CdSO4 and USF-1; CdSO4 and mot; nanoball-1 and nanoball-2. CdSO4 and USF-1 are uninodal nets with the same point (Schläfli) symbol, {65·8}, but they have different ideal linker geometries: (1) 180°, 180°, 90°; (2) 180°, 180°, 0° for CdSO4, and (1) 180°, 180°, 60°; (2) 180°, 180°, 0° for USF-1. Conversely, CdSO4 and mot have the same ideal geometry: (1) 180°, 180°, 90°; (2) 180°, 180°, 0°, but different point (Schläfli) symbols, {65·8} and {64·82}2{66} for CdSO4 and mot, respectively. For nanoball-1 and nanoball-2, they have the same requirement for θ = 120° (ψ and φ are complex) but different point (Schläfli) symbols for the polyhedra, {32·42·52} for nanoball-1 and {3·42·52}{3·43·5} for nanoball-2. 1,4-BDC will not form nanoball-1 and nanoball-2, since the θ angle for the linker is restricted to 120°. Although there are no examples of mot and USF-1 for 1,4-BDC, these topologies should be feasible for 1,4-BDC when considering the ideal geometries for these nets, since considerable distortion of the linker moieties can and does occur. For the Kagomé topology, the ideal angles are 180°, 150°, and 0° but the experimental angles for the two independent ligands in 1 are 120°, 165°, 17° and 120°, 163°, 17°. It appears that the restricted θ (120° for 1,3-BDC) is compensated by bend (ψ = 165° and 163°) and twist angles (φ = 17°). For the NbO topology, 2 exhibits angles of 120°, 163°, and 40°, which are significantly different from the ideal linker geometry (180°, 180°, and 90°). The restricted θ (120° for 1,3-BDC) is compensated by a large bend angle (ψ = 163°) and twist angle (φ = 40°). Therefore, the existence of 1 and 2 can be ascribed to the partial flexibility of a ligand that would ordinarily be considered to be rigid.
elements.clean_text: As mentioned earlier, Kagomé, square grid, and discrete nanoballs are the most commonly encountered nets when 1,3-BDC ligands serve as linkers for square paddlewheel moieties, although other supramolecular isomers such as USF-1, CdSO4, and MOF-112 nets have also been observed. We can now add NbO to this list, and the promiscuity of this system raises questions about how subtle geometric and steric factors might influence which nets will be obtained for a particular combination of nodes and linkers. The geometric features of 1,3-BDC or 1,4-BDC afford three geometric parameters that address bending or twisting as follows (Figure ): bending in the middle of the link by an angle θ; bending of the planes of the carboxylates by an angle ψ; twisting of the planes of the carboxylates about the linker axis relative to each other by an angle φ. We analyzed crystal structures that involve square paddlewheels linked by 1,3-BDC or 1,4-BDC, and the experimentally observed values of θ, ψ, and φ are presented in Table . 1,3-BDC forms Kagomé, square grid, nanoball-1, nanoball-2, CdSO4, USF-1, mot, and NbO nets, whereas 1,4-BDC is only known to exist as Kagomé, square grid, CdSO4, or NbO nets. It is interesting to note that six of these topologies can be grouped into three related pairs: CdSO4 and USF-1; CdSO4 and mot; nanoball-1 and nanoball-2. CdSO4 and USF-1 are uninodal nets with the same point (Schläfli) symbol, {65⋅8}, but they have different ideal linker geometries: (1) 180°, 180°, 90°; (2) 180°, 180°, 0° for CdSO4, and (1) 180°, 180°, 60°; (2) 180°, 180°, 0° for USF-1. Conversely, CdSO4 and mot have the same ideal geometry: (1) 180°, 180°, 90°; (2) 180°, 180°, 0°, but different point (Schläfli) symbols, {65⋅8} and {64⋅82}2{66} for CdSO4 and mot, respectively. For nanoball-1 and nanoball-2, they have the same requirement for θ = 120° (ψ and φ are complex) but different point (Schläfli) symbols for the polyhedra, {32⋅42⋅52} for nanoball-1 and {3⋅42⋅52}{3⋅43⋅5} for nanoball-2. 1,4-BDC will not form nanoball-1 and nanoball-2, since the θ angle for the linker is restricted to 120°. Although there are no examples of mot and USF-1 for 1,4-BDC, these topologies should be feasible for 1,4-BDC when considering the ideal geometries for these nets, since considerable distortion of the linker moieties can and does occur. For the Kagomé topology, the ideal angles are 180°, 150°, and 0° but the experimental angles for the two independent ligands in 1 are 120°, 165°, 17° and 120°, 163°, 17°. It appears that the restricted θ (120° for 1,3-BDC) is compensated by bend (ψ = 165° and 163°) and twist angles (φ = 17°). For the NbO topology, 2 exhibits angles of 120°, 163°, and 40°, which are significantly different from the ideal linker geometry (180°, 180°, and 90°). The restricted θ (120° for 1,3-BDC) is compensated by a large bend angle (ψ = 163°) and twist angle (φ = 40°). Therefore, the existence of 1 and 2 can be ascribed to the partial flexibility of a ligand that would ordinarily be considered to be rigid.

elements.content: In summary, we report herein how a bulky substituent in the 5-position of a 1,3-BDC moiety and a relatively bulky solvent molecule coordinated to the axial position of a square paddlewheel can afford the first NbO structure for a 1,3-BDC linker. We also address how the interplay between geometry (i.e., geometrical features associated with the linking BDC moieties) and steric effects (axially coordinated solvent) can influence the topology that is observed for a particular BDC ligand, 5-NPIA.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report herein how a bulky substituent in the 5-position of a 1,3-BDC moiety and a relatively bulky solvent molecule coordinated to the axial position of a square paddlewheel can afford the first NbO structure for a 1,3-BDC linker. We also address how the interplay between geometry (i.e., geometrical features associated with the linking BDC moieties) and steric effects (axially coordinated solvent) can influence the topology that is observed for a particular BDC ligand, 5-NPIA.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic information in CIF format and TGA, XRPD. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

cln_elements.content: To evaluate the stability of the two complexes, thermogravimetric analysis was conducted (). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits an initial weight loss about 1.5% to 80 °C, which can be ascribed to the loss of free ethanol (1.5% calculated) in the lattice. The sample is stable to 150 °C, at which point decomposition occurs. 2 exhibits much higher thermal stability (up to 292 °C without weight loss), but then an uninterrupted weight loss of ∼80% was observed, presumably corresponding to the loss of DMA molecules and decomposition of the framework.
cln_elements.clean_text: To evaluate the stability of the two complexes, thermogravimetric analysis was conducted (). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits an initial weight loss about 1.5% to 80 °C, which can be ascribed to the loss of free ethanol (1.5% calculated) in the lattice. The sample is stable to 150 °C, at which point decomposition occurs. 2 exhibits much higher thermal stability (up to 292 °C without weight loss), but then an uninterrupted weight loss of ~80% was observed, presumably corresponding to the loss of DMA molecules and decomposition of the framework.

The “partial flexibility” of 1,3-BDC can sustain twist angles of 0−90° or bend angles of up to 29.7°.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  The "partial flexibility" of 1,3-BDC can sustain twist angles of 0-90° or bend angles of up to 29.7°.

cln_elements.content: The geometry of 5-NPIA and the paddlewheel moieties: green, plane of the benzene ring in 5-NPIA; yellow, planes of the two carboxylate moieties of 5-NPIA.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  The geometry of 5-NPIA and the paddlewheel moieties: green, plane of the benzene ring in 5-NPIA; yellow, planes of the two carboxylate moieties of 5-NPIA.

cln_elements.content: The 2D layer of 1 (left) and its node and linker connectivity (right) that identifies it as a Kagomé lattice network.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  The 2D layer of 1 (left) and its node and linker connectivity (right) that identifies it as a Kagomé lattice network.

cln_elements.content: (a) Partially expanded net of 2 showing the NbO topology; (b) packing of the 3D structure of 2 viewed along the c axis. For clarity, the pyromellitic imide groups and coordinated DMA are omitted.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Partially expanded net of 2 showing the NbO topology; (b) packing of the 3D structure of 2 viewed along the c axis. For clarity, the pyromellitic imide groups and coordinated DMA are omitted.

cln_elements.content: The angles θ, ψ, and φ used to quantify the distortion of the 1,3-BDC and 1,4-BDC ligands.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  The angles θ, ψ, and φ used to quantify the distortion of the 1,3-BDC and 1,4-BDC ligands.

metadata.title: Consequences of Partial Flexibility in 1,3-Benzenedicarboxylate Linkers: Kagomé Lattice and NbO Supramolecular Isomers from Complexation of a Bulky 1,3-Benzenedicarboxylate to Cu(II) Paddlewheel Moieties
